channel.title: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound
channel.description:
So, I bought an Xbox 360 for 20 quid with a 120gb hdd and controller from a mate, because it was just lying around doing nothing, not bad? ikr. Turned it on at home for the first time, all works fine, except the fan was going almost as loud as a hair dryer within 30 seconds, I just dealt with it at that point, but 2 days later, I opened it up to see what the problem was.
Being 5 years old and never opened up, it was dusty as anything, figuring this may be the problem, I cleaned it out completely, removing fans separately and cleaning them with a cloth and cleaning the rest with a dyson hoover. Turned it on again, and still exactly the same, so I decided to begin removing the heatsinks.
After all that hassle, the cpu and gpu looked a little like this.
[url=http://img809.imageshack.us/img809/6281/19012011006.jpg]http://img809.imageshack.us/img809/6281/19012011006.jpg[/url]
[url=http://img683.imageshack.us/img683/1310/19012011007.jpg]http://img683.imageshack.us/img683/1310/19012011007.jpg[/url]
First of all, is that what it's meant to look like? I presume not, the 'lines' seen in the images were actually indents into the paste about 2mm deep, not sure why that could have happened, though I have no experience with thermal compounds.
So I put it all back together, putting the heat sinks and all the screws back in, and turned her on again. Within 10 seconds, it turned itself off due to overheating, giving the message on screen that it had done so.
I ensured the heat sinks were put back on tight, but I guess not tight enough.
Question is, is the thermal compound in need of replacement or not?
tl;dr, xbox overheats and turns off within 10 or so seconds, by looking at the images, is the thermal compound in need of replacement or is it something else?

item.title: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Used the arctic silver 5 and articlean on it today and it’s working great now, fan stays at the idle speed all the time, cheers guys

Read full topic
item.source: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound

item.title: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

The thermal compound on my CPU was so dry, I could easily rub it off with a paper towel.

Read full topic
item.source: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound

item.title: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

i found some nail polish remover in my parents’ house’s bathroom and that did the trick for me, worked really well

Read full topic
item.source: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound

item.title: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“fellixombc, post:8, topic:379693”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=475535.msg3477953#msg3477953 date=1295840919]
Rubbing alcohol actually didn’t really do too much for me, but I’m assuming I didn’t have a high enough percentage of alc. Who knows.
[/quote]
91% isopropyl alcohol worked fine for me. Nail polish remover should work as well.[/quote]I actually tried both.

Read full topic
item.source: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound

item.title: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Elijah:

Reapplying new thermal paste should also fix the issue with the fans being so loud also.

That’s what I was hoping to achieve, the fans are being put into overdrive because the sensors are telling them to, obviously

Read full topic

@fellixombc wrote:

Pwnd:

Rubbing alcohol actually didn’t really do too much for me, but I’m assuming I didn’t have a high enough percentage of alc. Who knows.

91% isopropyl alcohol worked fine for me. Nail polish remover should work as well.

item.title: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“fellixombc, post:5, topic:379693”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=475535.msg3477376#msg3477376 date=1295813114]
Alright cheers.

Would this do the job: http://www.amazon.co.uk/Arctic-Silver-Paste-Articlean-Cleaner/dp/B003VRBPAI/ref=dp_cp_ob_computers_title_1 ?
Or are there any alternatives?
[/quote]
Yeah, that would work fine. Although you don’t need any of that fancy cleaning stuff, you could just use rubbing alcohol instead.[/quote]

Okay thanks, I’ve actually spent more money getting this thing rigged up to my monitor and working than I spent on the console haha.

Read full topic

item.title: Topic concerning heat sinks and thermal compound
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“bootnecklad, post:2, topic:379693”]afaik, every time you take off any heat sink its a good idea to clean the area and reapply thermal paste.

Looking at those photos, I would defiantly replace the thermal paste if there is any on there at all.[/quote]
this.
never remove the fan unless you intend to replace the thermal compound

item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

Looking at those photos, I would defiantly replace the thermal paste if there is any on there at all.
